NORFOLK, Nov. 25.--As yet it has been impossible, owing to the imperfect telegraphic communication between this point and Kitty Hawk Signal Station to obtain a full and satisfactory account of the terrible disaster to the Huron, but scraps of information have been received which throw some light upon the matter. Kitty Hawk Signal Station is eight miles away from the scene of the wreck, and the intervening distance must be traversed by couriers.

RICHMOND, Nov. 24--Midnight.--The excitement in the lower part of the city is intense among the people, and the merchants doing business bolow the St. Charles Hotel, on Main-street, the point reached by the water during the great flood of 1870. They are moving the goods from stores and other places. The business streets are alive with vehicles of every kind, and people are engaged in the work of removal.

RICHMOND, Nov. 25.--A dispatch from Danville last night says: "The Dan River has risen to nearly the highest point ever known here. The damage in and about the city is more than $100,000 Everything bordering on the Dan River and the Big and Little Sandy Rivers has been swept away. The Virginia Midland Railroad has sustained much damage at this point.

The leaders were Major Kopesky, a Hungarian adventurer; Capt. De Leon Rodas, of the artillery; Jose Pavon, Enrique Gerzman, and Gabriel Aquilar, a priest. Mr. John H. Keyser was again before the Aldermanic Investigating Committee yesterday afternoon. He brought with him a large stock of account books and a capacious tin box, which were put alongside the witness, within convenient reach of his left hand. The attendance of spectators was large. Mr. Tweed was not so prompt in appearing as he had been on previous occasions, and he came without Mr. Townsend.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 26.--A heavy rainstorm prevailed here this morning between 4 and 6 o'clock, but it is believed to have been local. The waters of the flood at this point have fallen five feet up to this hour, (6 P.M.,) and are steadily subsiding, and it is expected that by to-morrow night the streets will be clear. The inundated portion of the city presents a scene of great devastation.
Chamberlain Tappan reports that the balance in the City Treasury is $3,403,028 21. The flags were at full mast yesterday over the City Hall in honor of Evacuation Day.

Harnett, under a foreclosure decree, by order of the Court of Common Pleas, Frank Rudd, Esq., Referee, sold the six-story brick store and tenement-house, with lot 25 by 103, No. 519 East 14th-st., north side, 266 feet east of Avenue A, for $10,000, to the Washington Life Insurance Company, plaintiff in the legal action.

The pilot left at 1 o'clock. I had the afternoon watch. There was a stiff breeze, and a heavy sea was running from the south-east.

"Evadue" was played last evening at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre. The piece is seldom revived in these days, and, in truth, its proper place is in the dramatic lumber-room of a dead past. Its author, Richard Lalor Shiel, delighted and amazed a generation by his eloquence, but he has not written a tragedy for all time.
Mr. Byrne sells coal in Louisville. The Boston bicyclists are to have a "meet" on Thanksgiving Day.

Senor M. Zamacona, formerly a member of the Mexican Claims Commission, and President of the Mexican Commission at the Centennial Exhibition, arrived at the Grand Hotel last evening from the City of Mexico. He comes to this country in the capacity of a special Commissioner to represent to our Government and people the sentiments of the Diaz Government with regard to the matters that are now in dispute between the two countries.

The news-boys of the Sixteenth Ward Lodging-house of the Children's Aid Society, No. 211 West Eighteenth-street, will be provided with a bountiful dinner of turkey, plum pudding, , on Thursday next by Mr. Theodore Roosevelt. Dinner will be served at 5 o'clock, after which the evening will be spent in various amusements. Friends of the lodging-house are cordially invited to be present.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 26.--The audience the greeted Oakey Hall in this city to-night was not a Boston audience--that is it was not a lecture audience. The great masses of the people, as the political orators say, were there. The men who attend the circus, the Graeco-Roman wrestling matches, the variety theatres, and the upper tiers of theatrical establishments, all turned out because they thought there would be some fun.

At the time of writing this it is still uncertain if the session may not last all night, since the Democrats have determined to make sure of their advantage, and, if possible, secure a vote on Mr. Thurman's resolution before adjournment.

The Republic Francaise demands the withdrawal of the new Cabinet, and renews its argument in favor of a Congress of the two Houses to definitely settle open constitutional questions. Several Conservative papers say the Government will call upon the Senate to declare openly for or against it.

The death of Mr. Moses H. Grinnell was a topic of general conversation in mercantile circles yesterday. Mr. Thurlow Weed spent several hours in recounting the character, life, and works of his deceased friend. He said that he could not be brief in speaking of such a large-hearted man as Mr. Grinnell. That gentleman's influences, always bright and genial, were seen and felt throughout the City for nearly half a century.

PARIS, Nov. 27.--The Budget Committee of the Chamber od Deputies will sit on Wednesday to deliberate upon the question of refusing to vote the Budget unless President MacMahon takes a Republican Cabinet. The Chamber is expected to decide this matter on Thursday.
Thomas Daft was to-day appointed Revenue Gauger for the Twenty second District of Pennsylvania. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $392,796 67, and from Customs $487,708.49.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--The published statements from the survivors of the Huron disaster, and the conversations with those of the officers who have arrived here, have changed the views of naval men and others in Washington concering the cause of the disaster. The first opinion entertained by nearly all was that the machinery of the vessel became disabled and left her at the mercy of the gale.

A snobbish preference for foreign productions robs the American painter of his just reward, and the want of an international Copyright law leaves the poor author heavily weighted in the competition against the best productions of English literature, supplied at prices which leave but a slender profit on priting, paper, and building.
